title: Trump has cut global climate finance. China is more than happy to step in.

title: Engine Maker Cummins Withdraws Its Outlook, Citing Uncertainty Over Tariffs
snippets:
Key Takeaways

  • Cummins on Monday withdrew its 2025 outlook, citing uncertainty about the impact of the Trump administration's tariffs.
  • The vehicle engine maker beat profit and sales estimates in the first quarter.
  • Shares of Cummins have lost about 12% of their value since the start of the year.


Engine maker Cummins (CMI) on Monday withdrew its 2025 outlook, citing uncertainty about the potential impact of the Trump administration's tariffs.

“Due to growing economic uncertainty driven by tariffs we have withdrawn our full year forecast,” CEO Jennifer Rumsey said, adding “we look forward to reinstating our forecast when conditions allow.”

Previously, Cummins had projected a revenue decline of 2% to rise of 3% year-over-year, with earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation, and amortization of 16.2% to 17.2% of sales. 

The company posted first-quarter earnings per share of $5.96, down from $14.03 a year earlier but above analysts' estimates compiled by Visible Alpha. While revenue fell 2.7% to $8.17 billion, that also topped expectations.

Sales at the firm’s Distribution, Power Systems, and Accelera units advanced, while they fell at its Engine and Components segments. 

Shares of Cummins gained about 2% in recent trading. They've lost about 12% of their value since the start of the year.
titles: Engine Maker Cummins Withdraws Its Outlook, Citing Uncertainty Over Tariffs
summary: Cummins, an engine manufacturer, announced it is withdrawing its 2025 financial outlook due to uncertainties caused by tariffs from the Trump administration. Despite this, the company reported first-quarter earnings and sales that exceeded analysts' expectations, with earnings per share of $5.96 and revenue of $8.17 billion. However, Cummins has experienced a 12% decline in share value since the beginning of the year. CEO Jennifer Rumsey expressed the company's intention to reinstate the forecast when conditions stabilize.
constructiveness_reason: This story provides empowering knowledge about the impact of tariffs on a major engine manufacturer, Cummins. It reports on the company's financial performance and its decision to withdraw its financial outlook due to uncertainties. This information could be useful for investors, policymakers, and others interested in the effects of trade policies on businesses.

title: These Common Bad Habits in Your 30s Can Damage Your Body and Mind for Decades

Addressing harmful lifestyle choices, such as smoking, excessive alcohol consumption, and physical inactivity, early in life is crucial for increasing the likelihood of a healthy and [...]
titles: These Common Bad Habits in Your 30s Can Damage Your Body and Mind for Decades

It emphasizes the importance of making early lifestyle changes to promote healthier aging, suggesting that addressing these harmful habits early on can increase the chances of maintaining good health later in life.

It increases awareness about the risks of smoking, heavy drinking, and physical inactivity, thus contributing to the reader's decision-making about lifestyle changes.

title: Taking This Popular Type of Medicine as an Infant Could Increase Your Risk of Obesity
snippets: Early antibiotic use is linked to higher BMI and increased obesity risk in children, according to a Finnish study of over 33,000 kids. Children who receive antibiotics during the first two years of life may be more likely to develop a higher body mass index (BMI) in later childhood, according to new research. The findings [...]
titles: Taking This Popular Type of Medicine as an Infant Could Increase Your Risk of Obesity
summary: A Finnish study involving over 33,000 children found that early antibiotic use in the first two years of life is associated with an increased risk of obesity in later childhood, as indicated by a higher body mass index (BMI).
constructiveness_reason: This story informs readers about the potential risks associated with early antibiotic use, contributing to a deeper understanding of the link between medication use in infancy and health outcomes in later childhood. However, it does not offer solutions or alternatives to antibiotic use, limiting its score.

title: Microplastics Are Invading Our Arteries, and It Could Be Increasing Your Risk of Stroke

People with plaque buildup in the arteries of their neck have been found to carry higher concentrations of tiny plastic particles within those blood vessels compared to individuals with healthy arteries. This difference [...]
titles: Microplastics Are Invading Our Arteries, and It Could Be Increasing Your Risk of Stroke
summary: Research has revealed that individuals with plaque buildup in their neck arteries, specifically the carotid arteries, have higher concentrations of microplastics compared to those with healthy arteries. This finding suggests a potential link between microplastic exposure and an increased risk of stroke.
constructiveness_reason: The story increases awareness about the potential health risks associated with microplastic exposure, providing useful context about its link to stroke risks. title: Scientists Expose a New Achilles’ Heel of Deadly Brain Cancer
snippets: Glioblastoma may be driven by 3D DNA folding patterns, not just mutations, offering new paths for treatment. A new preclinical study from researchers at Weill Cornell Medicine suggests that the way DNA folds inside the nuclei of brain cells could play a crucial role in understanding glioblastoma, a particularly aggressive and lethal form of brain [...]
titles: Scientists Expose a New Achilles’ Heel of Deadly Brain Cancer
summary: Researchers at Weill Cornell Medicine have discovered that the aggressive and deadly brain cancer, glioblastoma, may be influenced by the 3D folding patterns of DNA within brain cell nuclei, not just genetic mutations. This finding, from a preclinical study, opens up new potential avenues for treating the disease by targeting the structure of DNA.
constructiveness_reason: This story is highly constructive as it provides useful insights into a new potential treatment for glioblastoma, a deadly brain cancer. It reports on an innovative approach to the disease, focusing on the 3D folding patterns of DNA, and thus offers a new solution to a serious health problem.

title: One Vitamin, Two Discoveries: How B12 Prevents and Heals Acute Pancreatitis
snippets: Scientists have uncovered a surprising ally in the fight against acute pancreatitis: vitamin B12. Through genetic analysis and mouse model experiments, researchers showed that higher vitamin B12 levels can significantly reduce the severity of this often-deadly condition. Acute Pancreatitis: A Deadly Digestive Threat Acute pancreatitis (AP) is a serious gastrointestinal condition that affects people of [...]
titles: One Vitamin, Two Discoveries: How B12 Prevents and Heals Acute Pancreatitis
summary: Researchers have found that vitamin B12 plays a crucial role in both preventing and mitigating the severity of acute pancreatitis. Through genetic analysis and tests on mouse models, the study revealed that increased levels of vitamin B12 can significantly lessen the impact of this serious gastrointestinal disease.
constructiveness_reason: The story is constructive as it enhances the reader's understanding of the role of vitamin B12 in preventing and mitigating the severity of acute pancreatitis. It reports on a solution to a serious health issue and provides actionable insights (increasing vitamin B12 intake) for those at risk.
